YouTube™ Video: Analog Recommends: Day of Defeat Source 

			Views: 2,828		

			Join Trent as he tells you about one of the best FPS WWII shooters on PC that you might of missed out on! Written by Trent Video Capture and Editing by Valente		

Before the zeitgeist of perks, leveling and killstreaks consumed the multiplayer shooter market, Valve released an updated version of a successful team based World War 2 Half Life mod on their brand new engine and dubbed it Day of Defeat Source. Released in 2005, Day of Defeat was rooted in another industry fad—the world war 2 shooter. In the same year, Medal of Honor European Assault, Call of Duty 2, Brothers in Arms Road to Hill 30 and it's sequel Earned in Blood were all released. While the former games were largely single player story driven affairs, Day of Defeat Source was strictly a team based multiplayer game that distinguished itself by being extraordinarily balanced and offering phenomenal map design.  Players can enlist with either the U.S. Army or the German Wehrmacht and skirmish over capture points or attempt to arm bombs on strategic assets. Each side has six classes that utilize historic weaponry and almost every weapon sets itself apart from the opposite side's equivalent in some way. While the German's Mauser K98 is a single shot bolt action weapon that fires slower than the clip fed semi automatic Garand that the U.S. Army's rifleman class uses, it's also more powerful. Similarly, the Mauser M712 side arm carried by the German Panzerfaust units chews through enemies at close range but the M1 Carbine used by U.S. Rocket troops is far more versatile being semi automatic and highly effective at medium range. With these differences, players often built an allegiance to one army versus another based on their weapon preferences.  Each class also featured a set of quirks that required a bit of practice to master. Machine gunners couldn't effectively kill an enemy unless their gun was mounted, the recoil on these weapons is violent enough to have players staring at the sky box after pulling the trigger. This means that machine gunners are largely a defensive class along with snipers who are hopeless in mid range combat. The assault class utilizes early assault rifles which suffer from heavy recoil and are most effective when fired from a crouched position. Newcomers often favor the support class since their sub machine guns allow the kind of fast moving spray and pray tactics that modern shooter fans are accustomed to but the power and accuracy of rifle troops makes them easy prey at medium to long range where their automatic weapons are almost impotent. While it may be tempting to walk around with a rocket launcher, attempting to aim while moving is incredibly slow making players huge targets. These major differences in the play styles between classes make the experience rewarding and, in some cases, polarizing.  The six official maps offered with the game prove to be masterclasses of map design. In addition to the main lanes that take players to each objective, there are side routes that allow players to flank opponents and remove pesky snipers and machine gunners. Maps that are won by capturing all the territories feature a central capture point that requires at least two teammates to capture meaning it's impossible to go lone wolf and win a game. Uncoordinated teams will often find themselves entrenched in a bitter stalemate over these points—especially on Flash which is the most linear map of the bunch. Coordinating your teams efforts and making a big push toward an objective on multiple fronts often yields victory. It's a far cry from the lack of teamwork required by many modern shooter games. While six maps is a bit disappointing the community has stepped in to pad the play-list with hundreds of custom maps. Valve has continued to support Day of Defeat Source over the years, updating the game to include achievements and trading cards. It's mechanics are almost unrivaled almost a decade after release, in spite of the fact that the popularity of first person shooters has never abated. The aging visuals do little to hamper the thrill of rushing capture points and there are few things more satisfying than putting a bullet in an opponent's head while on the move with a K98. It's a shame that more shooters don't require the skill and cooperation demanded by Day of Defeat Source.

												I tried Day of Defeat: Source again recently and was expecting it to be dead. After all, the game is almost a decade old now. However, I was still able to find several populated servers at all hours of the day or night.  Old age hasn’t killed DOD:S.If anything age has worked in DOD:S’s favor. For example, it attracts an older and more mature crowd. I haven’t had to put up with as much drama or slurs from annoying prepubescent teammates as I do in more modern multiplayer shooters. Another example of age helping the DOD:S experience is how “old school” it feels. Despite the WW2 setting, DOD:S plays more like an arena shooter from the 1990s than today’s super serious military shooters. Forget aiming down iron sights. Secondary fire for most weapons throws solid punch instead. Expect to spend a lot of time zipping about, shooting dudes with crosshairs, punching them for good measure, and laughing at the exaggerated ragdoll physics. Day of Defeat: Source is not a masterpiece but it’s worth a look if you have a hankering for a shooter that isn’t too serious.

												Day of Defeat: Source was, just like Counter-Strike: Source, an update to Valve's new Source engine. I'm not aware at all of how the original Day of Defeat fared, as I never played it, therefore I can't make a proper comparison between the two.What I can talk about though, is obviously Day of Defeat: Source, having played it quite a bit and having fun with it. The game is set in WW2, and while a lot of games are set in WW2, nowadays with the massive trend of current and near future FPSes lately, it is remarkably a refreshing change.Source obviously made the maps and models look much better than the original game. They still hold up quite well nowadays, much like Source itself in any case, so for most people there won't be much of a problem when it comes to graphical fidelity.While I don't know how the gameplay in the original DoD was like, if it was anything like CS 1.6 to CS: Source, it may have ruffled a few feathers on the original DoD community upon DoD: Source's release. Or maybe it didn't, because of the gameplay.The gameplay is most definitely this game's strong point by a long shot. There are several classes to pick from, varied enough to justify their presence in the game, and fully suit the setting, just like the various weapons you have. The shooting feels good, just like most of the FPSes in Source.Unfortunately, it suffers from not having a whole lot of variety to it, both in game modes and in maps. And by now, there are naturally also other FPSes set in WW2 that feel and play a lot better than DoD: Source. There's still a community present, so you should have no difficulties jumping into a multiplayer game however.I would get this game. It's cheap and can be an enjoyable and refreshing game experience once in a while. Plus it's a Valve game, and those come with a lot of obvious perks. (Garry's Mod models being an example) Just don't expect too much out of it.

Day of Defeat: Source is my go to World War II shooter, and while it lacks any sort of singleplayer component, what it actually offers is surprisingly good. You play as either an Allied or Axis soldier and work with others on your team to accomplish specific goals, such as capturing objectives or capturing key locations. There are several classes to choose from, so everyone can hopefully find one they excel with. Visually, the game is (kinda/sorta) beautiful even these days, and the game's vibrant aesthetic style lends itself well to the Source engine that powers it. The models are pretty detailed, yet far from perfect. Moreover, the lighting of the game is actually a factor when picking your shots at other players, because it makes effective use of HDR lighting. So the light and dark colors contrast seamlessly. The weapons are also rendered quite realistically, and sound as such.Overall, this is a nice game that while being older, still has a decent playerbase and is tremendous fun. I particularly recommend this game!10/10 From Me Sweep

 It's a mad dash as I run to the entrance of the apartment complex. I narrowly dodge MG shots as I sprint through the door, German shouting and loud, continuous gunfire behind me. I eagerly make my way up the stairs as friendly soldiers run down past me. Upon reaching the top floor I greet an allied sniper only to see him get shot in the face. I wait a few good seconds before I peek out one of the windows to see several nazis running towards a capture point. Lifting my M1 Garand to my sights, I carefully follow along and wait for the opportune moment to strike... *crack!* *crack!* *crack!* *PING!* 2 dead, 3 running. I excitedly reload to take the next set of shots, when all of a sudden *BOOM* A panzerschreck round blasts me out of the window to the rubble below... Welcome to Day of Defeat: Source, a game where you will die often and love every second of it. There are many, many first-person shooters today, so much so that's it's a genre I'm beginning to feel fatigue for. But I can still appreciate when someone does it right. Make no mistake, DoD:S does it right. Guns feel heavy and real, gunshots have force and weight, and gunfights feel fair and rewarding. Every kill is earned here; there are no cheap weapons or exploits. Just you and your mouse. All the maps are paced great and feel distinct. The weapon choice is historically accurate and the guns really do feel like their real-world counterparts. Few shooters reach this level of polish and balance and I feel the need to call that out specifically. You might get this game and hate it at first cause everyone is accurate and quick and you can't seem to hit anything. But give it a week and start to get skilled and you'll understand the appeal of this bare-bones, good-time, heavy-hitting WWII FPS

												If you are a WW2 fan or you love hardcore shooters, this game is for you. Its a way different approach than say, Counter Strike. (You can't compare them and that's not what i'm going to do)You have 1 gamemode, it involves around capturing flags. There are two teams, the Americans are Germans. Both teams are treated equally (which is awesome, its not like the americans are the good guys and the nazis stupid germans that scream like a girl) and have six classes each with their own sets of weapons. Each class has a ranged attack, melee and explosives (grenades). Most of the classes get a backup pistol with them.The classes are: (German equipment first, the American and then what they share)- Rifleman (Mauser Kar89k, M1 Garand and rifle grenades) Has the ability to use ironsights and focuses on long-range combat.- Assault (MP40 and M1A1 Thompson, a smoke grenade and a frag grenade) For CQB.- Support (STG-44/MP-44 and B.A.R, 2 frag grenades) For mid and close range and surpressive fire.- Sniper (Kar98K Scoped and the M1903 Springfield Scoped). No grenades. For long range and to take out classes like other snipers and machinegunners.- Machinegunner (MG-42 and Browning M1919A4 (I think)) No grenades. Anti sniper, anti machinegunner and to take out large groups of enemies. Must be deployed using the bipod to shoot accurately. (hipfire not advised lol)- Rocket (not the rocket itself, the class) Uses a Panzershreck and M1 Bazooka. As a secondary you get the Mauser C96 or M1 Carbine (my fav). Anti Sniper and machinegunner.The classes all have the same health and speed. You die fast (in 1-3 shots, always 1 shot headshot) and rushing is not advised. The game is extremely faced paced and competitive. You need to work together as a team, use your microphone or voice commands to communicate. The voice commands are awesome and well voiced. Besides that you have the option to go prone (using Z as default I think) This greatly reduced recoil and makes you harder to hit. The disadvantage of it is that when to go prone or out of prone you holster your weapon for 1-2 seconds. I've died many times of this. You get used to it after a while, though. Another option is to sprint. There is a stamina bar that lets you sprint for a few seconds. You cannot shoot while sprinting. In the realism modes, when you get shot in your arm, you drop your primary weapon. A pretty neat feature, but annoying at the same time.The gunplay itself it pretty well done, it has the same feature as Counter Strike when you are standing still, you accuracy with the most guns is near perfect and when you are moving your accuracy decreases. Almost all the guns have massive recoil, and I mean massive, it takes a lot of skill to master.The base game comes with a lot of maps and many custom maps too which I don't care about. The stock maps are good and have cool shortcuts and offer a lot of replay value.There is no singleplayer unless you download a bot mod, which I haven't tried. There are plenty of multiplayer servers to choose from.The servers mostly consist of 32 player slots, which means 16 vs 16 players.For active servers DON'T use the serverbrowser, its broken, use Gametracker to locate servers instead. The EdgeGamers servers are pretty good, their clan is EgO (I think). These servers have all the realism settings turned off and have a medic mod that lets you call a medic by typing !medic in the chat. I advise binding this to a key. The medic only heals when your health is below 25 HP (that is when the healthbar turns red). Ping isn't a problem really, but above 150 ping the game becomes unplayable (no ♥♥♥♥ sherlock)There are a lot of realism servers too, but its your choice on what to play.Community is awesome and mostly mature players. There are daily around 900-1100 players online across all regions.The game runs almost on every system, I have no problems with it really, and I have a low end PC.What I hate about Day of Defeat is the constant explosive spam. Grenades deal massive damage and get spammed mostly in doorways and passages. You have the option to throw the grenades back, but this is hard to do. Best to counter the spam is to flank the enemy.Do I recommend it? Heck yes!TL:DR: great game I advise you buy it, its worth the full price or wait for steam sale and buy the Valve multiplayer pack. Same price and comes with CSS. (For Gmod textures lol)

												In light of the low purchase price, worth a play!Despite the historical setting, it's definitely not attempting to be realistic or historic at all.  The performance, availability, and use of weapons is heavily adjusted for "play balance" rather than realism.For example, although the real M1 Garand and Mauser 98K would have had very similar performance, in terms of ability to wound/kill with a single shot, in game the 98K has been made quite easy to score one-shot kills and the Garand seems to typically require two shots to offset it's rate of fire.Every "Rifleman" also seems to be a grenadier, with a rifle grenade launcher and for some odd reason without hand grenades.  This deprives the German rifleman of his signature "potato masher" grenades.Pistols are far too common, and for some odd reason seem to do more damage per shot than the SMGs, which is exactly opposite of reality.The BAR is frequently used as more of a heavy assault rifle than an LMG as it properly should be.  The StG-44 on the other hand has been given extra recoil in order to make it into some kind of "German BAR", when in fact this is completely wrong.  It was the first assault rifle, and should combine the lethality of a rifle like the Mauser or Garand with the low recoil of an SMG like the Thompson or MP-40.  It really should be easy to use, incredibly deadly, and also incredibly rare.The G-43/K-43 semi-automatic rifle that the Germans fielded is completely missing, and the Bazooka and Panzerschreck, which would have been far too valuable to waste against infantry targets, are used as if they were primarily an anti-personnell weapon.In other words, there's no realism, so don't look for it.But when it's on sale for $2, it's an OK buy.

er 27, 2010
												My gaming life has revolved around Day of Defeat after my fascination with Half-Life, the mods that came of it, and my family. My brother John (Fuzz) (I use his pseudonym because I look up to my brother and the name is catchy to me) and a few programmers at the time came up with the initial concept of DoD after my brother watched Saving Private Ryan. At an early age (8 or 9) I would watch my brother create sandbox levels within his newly created mod, Day of Defeat. My brother paved the way for Day of Defeat before his departure of the development team (focus on school and relationships) shortly before Valve purchased the mod and turned it into a Valve product. Soon after my father (Wes) (Fuzzdad) would join in on the efforts to help propel the game forward with level design. My father was a Major in the Army and a helicopter pilot for 13 years, to say he loves history is an understatement. His dedication to the game and meticulous craftsmanship of design with each level was researched, designed, tested, redesigned and re-tested for countless hours. I vividly remember walking downstairs on more than one occasion to his mancave and watching him design what is now known as dod_glider with the Hammer tool, Valve Software's map creation program for their game engine. I am grateful that my father allowed me to playtest his maps and give input. Fuzzdad went on to be a Valve-contracted level designer for dod_glider, dod_flugplatz and dod_falaise. He also created custom maps such as dod_factory and dod_Anvil (Made on Source) Fuzzdad worked directly with Matt Boone (Main Programmer for DoD/DoD:s and now works on multiple Valve games, also known as Mugsy) with game changes, community map pack releases, updates to stock maps, texture files, sounds, etc. I commend Mugsy for sticking it out as long as he did with DoD/DoD:S by helping the community and working with my father to better the game.Day of Defeat and Day of Defeat: Source are my favorite multiplayer FPS. It is evident Valve gave up on Day of Defeat: Source after Sourcefilms was tested with DoD:S (The trailers referring to specific maps like Donner) It's hard to blame Valve for lack of content or continuous updates with the game not breaking even on sales. The WW2 era FPS from the 90s and early 2000's has lost the populace favor but that doesn't mean this game is anything less than great.Do I recommend this game? Yes, yes and yes. DoD:S is a majestic game that has countless replay value and at its core is fun. It's realistic in terms of 1-2 bullet kills. While there is only one "true" gamemode (CTF) they also have demolition style maps, but the majority of what's left of public servers play CTF or realism. I personally wish they would release a steam workshop for the game or add gamemodes, but it would be safe to say DoD:S has lost it's prime motivation that it once had years ago. What's left of public servers is mostly realism units which you may or may not like (I personally find them more like a person trying to relive his/her military past and not fun in terms of gameplay) but you as a player might find that style of play different or fun.To conclude: Day of Defeat will always be a part of me and my future endeavours in gaming and I hope you the reader give this game a try, even if it's not in its prime anymore. It's still enjoyable to pub once in a while.I'll always have hope for a new DoD, maybe one day, maybe never, but I'll always have my memories of this great game.

												Lets be real. Day of Defeat: Source is a old game. (2006 to be exact) It was built on Source, the engine Valve engineered for Half-Life 2, Day of Defeat: Source features amazing graphics and physical gameplay for its time back in 2006. The main object of the game is to cap all the flags and then the round is over. Most servers that you play on unless its a 24 hour server of the same map will then change after one team caps all the flags 5 times. Day of Defeat: Source is kind of like a WW2 game of Counter Strike but with this game you can respown after you die before the round is over. There has always been cool mods for this game that make you crawing back for more and more. Game mods like Left 4 Dead (DoD:S) stile, realism mod and gun game just to name a few. The game is smooth and movement at times can feel like your just floating while in movement. What keeps me interested is the fact that the game is easy to learn but hard to master. You have to learn how to compensate for recoil of every firing weapon in the game. If you are not happy with the sights that are the defalt sights you can always change them to your liking to diffrent cross hairs and diffrent colors. There are not that many set backs to the game besides that all the models are the same. However you can go on Gamebanana and download any skin you may like and change it up a bit even change the weapon skin. At times you might feel like your team is at a disadvantage because of your map postion but thats again is what keeps you into the game. The number one thing that will keep you into the game is the community. This community is very helpful with any questions you may have about the game. Just know that if you have never played Day of Defeat: Source dont expect it to be like a Call of Duty game that is easy to play. Like said before this game is easy to learn but hard to master. Before you start to play just know your going to die and die a lot but, with time and good practice you will start to become better. Dont expect it to be like a Call of Duty game that is all about how many kills you get per round but more so about just having fun with other players. Most if not all hard core Day of Defeat: Source players HATE Call of Duty and do not appreciate when little kids talk all about how Call of Duty is so much better. The game is very cheep for what you get and you will not be let down.

												Warning: TL;DRMe and Jim run for the door. Alex is swift to follow. Towards us come a hail of bullets, and I clasp my sniper firmly in my hands. The Wehrmacht are capturing buildings to make sure their attack works. Not if we can help it. This building will remain ours. Jim picks up his SMG and aims it at the corners. Me and Alex follow behind him, as our weapons aren't suited for the close quarters. I have a sniper. He, a mount-machinegun.The explosions outside are deafening, and the enemy fire has started again. In comes a fellow american soldier with his SMG. He runs ahead of Jim in a hurry. I don't know why. He enters the next room swiftly. We hear gunfire. Then we see him fall to the ground like a puppet. We know what to do. Jim throws a grenade into the next room. We hear shouting, and then a loud explosion followed by a final scream. A german helmet lands in front of us.Me, Jim, and Alex run up the stairs. Jim guards the stairs, just like he said he would. Alex mounts his machinegun on the windowsill, and I look through the scope and look out the window.I see hell, as dozens of Wehrmacht soldiers storm houses and execute our fellow american soldiers. Alex can't watch anymore. Wehrmacht take cover as Alex mow them down. American soldiers still fighting in the streets, being shot by snipers from other buildings thank us, though many lose their lives because of the Wehrmacht. Only the ones taking complete cover still live. And yet, a large group of US forces enter the street from home base, half of them shot to death by the large force of Wehrmacht machinegunners and snipers.Suddenly, Alex just falls down, and his helmet rolls of his head. Blood oozes out through his forehead. I will never forget the shock on Jim's face, and the expression on the face of the corpse.My turn. I like through the scope and look to the windows of Nazi-occupied windows. I pass a lot of empty windows, but then I see one with a sniper. He is aiming down the scope to the streets, right at the head of an american soldier. CRACK. Fire erupts from the barrel of the sniper, and the soldier lies dead. Now the sniper is aiming at another soldier. My turn. CRACK. A bullet meets his head, and I am happy to have fired it. His helmet flies off. I now look to the streets. A group of Wehrmacht are taking cover behind the remnants of a wall, one of them being a machinegunner, firing hundreds of bullets per second. CRACK. His gun stops shooting, and while the gunner hits the ground, the group look for me. I get down to hide, but It's too late. One of them saw me, and now shouts "Scharfschütze!"A loud BANG erupts, and the oddly loud noise of a swish hits me. I realize what happened. A german must have fired a Panzerschrek towards me. I yell at Jim to take cover, and then a rocket hits the wall next to the window. I go deaf for a moment. Then I hear German soldier yelling at eachother below me. Jim looks at me with the face he makes when he is scared. Then he looks back down the stairs.German boots hit the ground. Sweat runs off the palms of both of us. I try telling him we need to parachute out the window, to escape, but Jim refuses. "Stick to the plan," he says. Then he starts firing.I can tell he's having trouble with the recoil, because soon the bullets go further up, and a Nazi has a chance to aim at him and...The Wehrmacht soldier pulls the trigger. Jim stops shooting. Jim just looks at the ground. Then a great red puddle forms beneath him. Jim is dead. Alex is dead. That american soldier we just met. Dead. I have two choices. Jump out the window, or avenge Jim (or die trying). Second option sounds appealing. I will never bow down to this tyranny. I am a soldier, and I will fight it.I approach the stairs. I know I am going to die. I know we are going to lose this battle. But to me, that doesn't matter. I will be together with my brothers, and every day of defeat, is another chance at victory.

												Even though this game is starting to  look  rather dated, the mechanics are still great. This game is one of the most well-made and well-polished FPS-game there is. It has silky-smooth animations, rock-solid gameplay mechanics and proper, realistic sound design. This game is what we call a no-boshiet experience. It is clean, well made and solid. If you are looking for a game that offers a proper solid FPS-experience set within a realistic setting and playing with serious yet helpful people, this is the game for you. But if you are looking for a game that has plenty of deep grinding/leveling-features with killstreaks and ballistic knifes, this game is far from anything you would enjoy. If you long back to the days of when online FPS-games were pure, solid and required skill, yet don't like that kick of nostalgia, then go for Day of Defeat: Source.
